Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of ROTEM®-Guided Transfusion Strategy in Obstetric Haemorrhage

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation and blinding details are not applicable as this was a retrospective analysis.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at the Rotunda Hospital, Dublin, this trial included 944 women experiencing PPH ≥1500 ml over five years.

Intervention.evidence: evaluate the effectiveness of a ROTEM®-guided transfusion strategy compared to conventional transfusion methods

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a ROTEM®-guided transfusion strategy compared to conventional transfusion methods in managing postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) ≥1500 ml.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the overall consumption of blood coagulation products, measured over one year post-implementation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and blinding details are not applicable as this was a retrospective analysis.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and blinding details are not applicable as this was a retrospective analysis.

Number_Randomised.evidence: this trial included 944 women experiencing PPH ≥1500 ml over five years

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were retrospectively analysed, with 238 women in the post-ROTEM® group and 706 in the pre-ROTEM® group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The post-ROTEM® group showed a 46% reduction in fibrinogen concentrate use, a 72% decrease in Octaplas®, and a 79% reduction in platelet use, resulting in a cost saving of €51,738.
